sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction below, given the standard enthalpy of formation values: 
2CO(g) + O2(g) → 2CO2(g)

ΔH°f (CO) = -110.5 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (O2) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ [ΔH°f (products)] - Σ [ΔH°f (reactants)]

For this reaction, the products are 2 moles of CO2 and the reactants are 2 moles of CO and 1 mole of O2.

ΔH° = [2 × ΔH°f (CO2)] - [2 × ΔH°f (CO) + ΔH°f (O2)]

Now, we can plug in the given standard enthalpy of formation values:

ΔH° = [2 × (-393.5 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (-110.5 kJ/mol) + 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH° = [-787 kJ] - [-221 kJ]

ΔH° = -566 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -566 kJ.
